sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The burning bush not consumed wherein (either vnder all deepe sense of wrath; or hardnesse of heart, one may iudge, whether he be the childe of God, or not, &c. Chiefly receyuing satisfaction concerning the sinne against the Holy Ghost. Perused by I.D. and diuers other diuines. Hart, John, D.D. Dyke, Jeremiah, 1584-1639, attributed name.
[28], 158, [6] p.
Printed by T[homas] C[reede] and B[ernard] A[lsop] for Roger Iackson, and are to be solde at his shoppe in Fleet-streete, ouer against the great Conduite, London : 1616.
Editor's dedication signed "I. Hart" = John Hart. I.D. = Jeremiah Dyke?. A dialogue between a minister and a scholar. Printers' names from STC. "A prayer for the distressed", M6-8. Running title reads: A discouery of the child of God, vnder all sense of seeming wrath. The title page is a cancel. Variant: title page is conjugate; comma after "bush"; line 11 reads ".. ond diners [sic] other diuines.". Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
=======
The burning bush not consumed wherein (either vnder all deepe sense of wrath; or hardnesse of heart, one may iudge, whether he be the childe of God, or not, &c. Chiefly receyuing satisfaction concerning the sinne against the Holy Ghost. Perused by I.D. and diuers other diuines. Hart, John, D.D. Dyke, Jeremiah, 1584-1639, attributed name.
[28], 158, [6] p.
Printed by T[homas] C[reede] and B[ernard] A[lsop] for Roger Iackson, and are to be solde at his shoppe in Fleet-streete, ouer against the great Conduite, London : 1616.
Editor's dedication signed "I. Hart" = John Hart. I.D. = Jeremiah Dyke?. A dialogue between a minister and a scholar. Printers' names from STC. "A prayer for the distressed", M6-8. Running title reads: A discouery of the child of God, vnder all sense of seeming wrath. The title page is a cancel. Variant: title page is conjugate; comma after "bush"; line 11 reads ".. ond diners [sic] other diuines.". Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.
Roger Iackson
B[ernard] A[lsop]
T[homas] C[reede]
his shoppe in Fleet-streete, ouer against the great Conduite
